qas.question: In the United States, what was federalism referred to?

answers.text: belief in a stronger central government.

qas.question: When the U.S Constitution was being drafted, what did the federalist party support?
On the political spectrum, where does federalism stand?

answers.text: federalism" is situated in the middle of the political spectrum between a confederacy and a unitary state

plausible_answers.text: belief in a stronger central government

qas.question: In the United States, what wasn't federalism referred to?
When the U.S Constitution was being erased, what did the federalist party support?
When the U.S Constitution was being drafted, what did the federalist party oppose?

plausible_answers.text: in the middle of the political spectrum between a confederacy and a unitary state

qas.question: On the political spectrum, where doesn't federalism stand?

context: In the United States, federalism originally referred to <a0_0><b4_0>belief in a stronger central government<b4_0/>.<a0_0/> When the U.S. Constitution was being drafted, the Federalist Party supported a <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>stronger central government<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>, while "Anti-Federalists" wanted a <a2_0><b7_0>weaker central government<b7_0/><a2_0/>. This is very different from the modern usage of "federalism" in Europe and the United States. The distinction stems from the fact that "<a3_0>federalism" is situated <b8_0>in the middle of the political spectrum between a confederacy and a unitary state<b8_0/><a3_0/>. The U.S. Constitution was written as a reaction to the Articles of Confederation, under which the United States was a loose confederation with a weak central government.
